digital-scale.name: Digital scale
digital-scale.description: Precision scale for measuring oils, lye, and additives by weight. Essential for accurate soap formulation.
digital-scale.details:
Volume-based measuring is not precise enough for soapmaking. A good scale should have at least 0.1g precision for small batches and handle up to 5kg for larger batches.

Look for scales with a tare function to zero out container weight. Waterproof or splash-resistant models are ideal since you'll be working with liquids.
considerations: Precision: 0.1g for small batches, 1g acceptable for large batches

stick-blender.name: Stick blender (immersion blender)
stick-blender.description: Handheld immersion blender used to emulsify oils and lye solution, dramatically reducing time to trace.
stick-blender.details:
A stick blender can reduce mixing time from the 30 to 60 minutes expected if stirring by hand to 2 to 5 minutes. Use short bursts of 2 to 3 seconds, alternating with stirring to avoid overmixing and reaching trace too quickly.

It's good to dedicate a stick blender to soapmaking, since the alkalinity of raw soap can degrade seals over time, and the additives used in soap can transfer back into food if you're not careful with cleaning.
considerations: Stainless steel shaft (not aluminium, which reacts with lye)
safetyNotes: Never use while lye solution is hot
Keep blade submerged to avoid splashing

silicone-mould.name: Silicone mould
silicone-mould.description: Flexible silicone moulds for shaping soap.
silicone-mould.details:
Silicone moulds are popular as they allow soap to release easily without sticking.

Loaf moulds create bars that need cutting. Individual cavity moulds produce ready-to-use bars but may show partial gel phase rings.

Silicone insulates well, which increases the likelihood of gel phase if using loaf moulds. For non-gel soap, use individual cavities or freeze the mould.
considerations: Wall thickness affects insulation and gel phase

wooden-loaf-mould.name: Wooden loaf mould
wooden-loaf-mould.description: Traditional wooden box mould lined with freezer paper or silicone. Provides excellent insulation for gel phase.
wooden-loaf-mould.details:
A classic choice for cold process soap. They insulate well, promoting even gel phase throughout the loaf.

Must be lined with freezer paper (shiny side toward soap) or a silicone liner. Unlined wood will absorb moisture and soap, becoming unusable.
considerations: Heavier and less flexible than silicone
Can be made DIY to custom sizes

safety-goggles.name: Safety goggles
safety-goggles.description: Chemical splash goggles that seal around the eyes to protect against lye splashes.
safety-goggles.details:
Regular glasses or safety glasses with open sides are not sufficient to protect against vapours or random splashes that can cause serious eye injury.

Choose goggles rated for chemical splash protection (ANSI Z87.1 or equivalent), with indirect ventilation to prevent fogging while keeping liquids out.
considerations: Chemical splash rated (not just impact rated)
Should fit over prescription glasses if needed
safetyNotes: Wear whenever handling lye or raw soap
Keep within arm's reach of workspace

references.section: ANSI/ISEA Z87.1 Eye and Face Protection
references.note: American standard for occupational eye and face protection

rubber-gloves.name: Rubber gloves
rubber-gloves.description: Chemical-resistant gloves to protect hands from lye and raw soap batter.
rubber-gloves.details:
Nitrile or neoprene gloves provide good protection against sodium hydroxide. Latex is acceptable but may degrade faster with repeated exposure.

Choose gloves long enough to cover wrists.
considerations: Nitrile or neoprene preferred over latex
Length: wrist-length minimum, elbow-length for large batches
Replace immediately if torn or punctured
safetyNotes: Wear whenever handling lye or raw soap
Check for holes before each use
Wash gloves before removing to prevent drips

references.note: Chemical resistance guidance for protective equipment

thermometer.name: Thermometer
thermometer.description: Temperature measuring device for monitoring oil and lye solution temperatures before combining.
thermometer.details:
The mixed melted fat and lye solution should ideally start at  100-130°F (38-54°C) to prevent false trace.

Infrared (non-contact) thermometers are convenient but measure surface temperature only. Probe thermometers give more accurate readings.
considerations: Probe type more accurate than infrared for liquids

soap-cutter.name: Soap cutter
soap-cutter.description: Tool for cutting loaf soap into uniform bars; knives, wire-based cutters, adjustable multi-bar cutters...
soap-cutter.details:
Timing matters: cut too early and bars may stick together or deform; too late and very hard soap may crack or be difficult to cut.

Most cold process soap is ready to cut 24 to 48 hours after pouring, when firm but still slightly soft. High-olive recipes may need longer.
considerations: Wire cutters: clean cuts, minimal drag
Knife: more control but may drag through soft soap
Mitre box: helps achieve straight cuts

mixing-containers.name: Mixing containers
mixing-containers.description: Heat-resistant containers for mixing lye solution and combining with oils. Must be lye-safe materials.
mixing-containers.details:
For lye, use heat-resistant plastic (PP #5, HDPE #2), stainless steel, or tempered/borosilicate glass. NEVER use aluminium, as it reacts violently with lye.

For soap batter, use stainless steel or heavy-duty plastic pitchers. A pour spout helps with moulding.
safetyNotes: Check recycling code on plastic (PP #5 or HDPE #2 only)
Inspect for cracks before each use

curing-rack.name: Curing rack
curing-rack.description: Open-air rack for curing soap bars. Allows air circulation on all sides for even water evaporation.
curing-rack.details:
Soap needs 4 to 6 weeks of curing time after cutting. During this period, water evaporates and the crystal structure matures, resulting in harder, milder bars.

Good air circulation prevents soft spots and speeds curing. Avoid direct sunlight, as it can fade colours and cause uneven curing.
considerations: Open design for air circulation on all sides
Sturdy enough to hold multiple batches
Place in cool, dry area with good airflow
